summary: An internal email from Deutsche Bank associate Amanda Kirby advocating for the approval of a $250,000 payment for Jeffrey Epstein's plane, emphasizing his immense wealth, his role in introducing other ultra-wealthy clients to the bank, and the significant financial risk of losing his business.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Described as an extremely wealthy client worth roughly $18 billion, who is introducing other billionaire clients to Deutsche Bank and whose continued business is deemed critical.

persons.name: Amanda Kirby
persons.role: Associate, Deutsche Bank Trust Company Americas
persons.context: Author of the email, advocating for the approval of a transaction for Jeffrey Epstein and detailing his importance to the bank.

persons.name: Paul Morris
persons.context: Identified as the private banker on the team that Jeffrey Epstein has been introducing to other clients.

connections.description: Kirby is a bank associate advocating for Epstein's financial transaction and describing his critical importance as a client.
Epstein has been introducing the private banking team, led by Paul Morris, to other potential billionaire clients.

events.title: Request for $250k Aircraft Payment
events.description: Amanda Kirby sends an email requesting approval for a $250,000 payment from Jeffrey Epstein to Insured Aircraft Title Services for one of his planes.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein's net worth is estimated at roughly $18 billion in this 2014 communication.
Epstein had approximately $230 million deposited at Deutsche Bank at the time, with an expected additional $100 million.
Epstein was instrumental in introducing Deutsche Bank to at least four other potential clients, each capable of depositing over $250 million.
The bank viewed losing Epstein as a client as a major risk, fearing it would cause the majority of his referred prospects to walk away.
The document reveals Deutsche Bank's internal prioritization of a high-value client's transactions despite potential red flags.
